editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Arctius, and many others. as the Orthodox affirm. Now for commands, there can be no di≈øpen≈øation to binde us to obedience; without di≈øpute, the word [as often] doth not leave us to liberty, when and how often we plea≈øe to communicate,
to u≈øe or not to u≈øe it. Jeanes, pag. 5. There can be no ≈øuch conclu≈øion drawn from hence, but he teacheth us what we mu≈øt doe, as often as according to the command of Chri≈øt, we celebrate it, viz: to ≈øhew forth the death of Chri≈øt. div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: The ≈øeverall Objections for the long Omi≈øsion of the Lords Supper an≈øwered.

div.p: I Come now to tho≈øe Objections I finde and have heard alledged for the long Omi≈ø≈øion of the Lords Supper, to u≈øe rather their own term, the ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of it for the pre≈øent.

Fir≈øt, though it be granted that there be a command, yet it is affirmative, and it is an old rule in Divinity, Affirmativa praecepta ≈øemper obligant, non ad ≈øemper, Affirmative precepts doe alwaies binde, but not to alwaies: ≈øo that we are not thus to perform alwaies what they command, but onely Loco ac tempore debitis, when we have due time and place; ≈øo that pro h√Æc & nunc, they may cea≈øe to be obligatory, as when ≈øcandall will en≈øue, or, there is not a fit ≈øea≈øon and opportunity to doe what is commanded. To this I will give you the an≈øwer of a late Orthodox Divine, We mu≈øt put a difference between a tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion of a precept, and a temporary or occa≈øional forbearance of the matter commanded. No precept what≈øoever is for the e≈øchewing the ≈øcandall of any to be broken or tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed, and if a precept be not tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed, where what is enjoyned in it is wholly and altogether omitted, I leave it to cen≈øure: totally to ab≈øtain from what they command, is ≈øinfully to omit what is commanded by them. Many wicked, Object. 2 and ungodly people thru≈øt in them≈øelves to the Sacraments with the faithfull, which is a great abu≈øe, and therefore to be forborn for a time untill there be a power to debarre them.

Fir≈øt, our charity ≈øhould begin at home, An≈øwer. and our greate≈øt care ≈øhould be how to avoid ≈øin in our ≈øelves, and not over-≈øollicitous how to prevent it in others: We ≈øhould not let ≈øin lye on others without reproof, yet not omit a nece≈ø≈øary Ordinance for the ≈øin of any. It is no inconvenience to profe≈ø≈øe that we are all one vi≈øible body in the Lords Supper,Rea≈øons for Separation di≈øcu≈ø≈øed. 1 Cor. 10.17. though we be not one invi≈øible, true, and my≈øticall, and redeemed body of Chri≈øt, as it is ≈øaid, 1 Cor. 10.2. Fir≈øt, An≈øw. 1 that in a con≈øtituted Church where there is a ≈øetled government, and per≈øons that have power to ≈øu≈øpend and excommunicate upon ju≈øt and legall proof of Witne≈ø≈øes, ≈øuch per≈øons ≈øo convicted, and adjudged guilty, ought not to be admitted, till repentance and publick confe≈ø≈øion make way for their admi≈ø≈øion, all ≈øinners quatenus ≈øinners are not to be exempted. Fourthly, by way of An≈øwer to the Objection. Thirdly, all ignorant per≈øons that doe not di≈øcern the Lords body, that have not the knowledge of God, of them≈øelves, and the doctrine of the Sacraments, and other nece≈ø≈øary points of Religion.

Fiftly, all prophane, ungodly, and malicious wretches, all Drunkards, Adulterers, Bla≈øphemers, Contemners of God, &c. if the≈øe ≈øhould be admitted (after they are legally tried and found out to be ≈øuch, and by authority adjudged) the Church of God would be a ≈øynagogue of Sathan, the fellow≈øhip of Saints a ≈øtye of ≈øwine, a ≈øtable of bea≈øts, a cage of unclean birds. But the que≈øtion is not whether ≈øuch ≈øhould be debarred, but who hath the power of debarring from the Sacrament; for ≈øeeing the cen≈øure of the Church it doth not belong to private per≈øons, it is not in their power to draw out of the cen≈øures of the Church again≈øt notorious offenders, but in the Governours of it.
But here it may be demanded whether the Mini≈øter in the want of government may not ≈øu≈øpend his own act,Dem. and hold his hands from giving the Sacrament to one that he knows to be prophane.

It is thought by mo≈øt he may not for the Rea≈øons afore alledged: it is an act that belongs to the Church-Officers, and would introduce a world of tyranny, and few could a≈ø≈øure them≈øelves the benefit of Receiving, if the Mini≈øter had this unlimited power. Others ≈øee no rea≈øon but in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity a Mini≈øter may ≈øu≈øpend his own act of giving it to one (whom of his own knowledge) he knows may be drunk, and the like, and this is not a cen≈øure, but Gradus ad cen≈øuram. The Idolaters, by the light of Nature, would not ≈øuffer all to approach their Sacrifices, but cried out, That prophane men mu≈øt be packing: ≈øuch as have a clear fountain of water delivered to them mu≈øt not ≈øuffer any to trouble and annoy the water, but mu≈øt endeavour to keep them back by powerfull arguments of the danger of unworthy receiving; which for all that, if they dare go on (and there be no government in the Church) then to keep back his hand from reaching that to him which he knows will aggravate their judgments. Every Pa≈øtor is to have a Pa≈øtoral care of any of his flock, and he hath a power of order and juri≈ødiction, as a Watchman, though not of Church-juri≈ødiction, which belongeth to Church-Officers. This is done by the Law of Charity, and not Ex officio, by authority. Every man by Divine Law is his Brothers keeper, and mu≈øt not ≈øuffer ≈øin to lie on him, which is no more than Sublevatio mi≈øeriae peccantis, the ≈øuccouring of the mi≈øery of a ≈øinner; or act of prudence, mercy, and compa≈ø≈øion: E≈ø≈øe benevolentiam potius qu√†m ≈øeveritatem, Rather clemency than ≈øeverity; charitatem potius e≈ø≈øe qu√†m pote≈øtatem, Rather an act of charity than power: he doth but the part of a friend, Aut praevenire errori, aut revocare errantem, Either to prevent a man before he erre, or to call him from erring.
But this I leave to the cen≈øure of my brethren, for to be determined by me is ≈øaucy pre≈øumption.
From a promi≈øcuous receiving by wicked and ungodly, Object. 4 there is a great deal of ≈øcandal or offence given.
That which is perfectly good cannot be the occa≈øion of evil, An≈øw. 1 as the Sacrament of the Lords Supper. Indeed, that which ≈øimply and of it ≈øelf cau≈øeth evil, is evil it ≈øelf.

Secondly, know notorious ≈øinners proved to be ≈øuch ought
not to be admitted in a con≈øtituted Church where there is a ≈øetled Government.
Thirdly, none but the Officers of the Church have power of Church-cen≈øure.

Fourthly, that in the want of Government a Mini≈øter ought to u≈øe all means po≈ø≈øible for the removing of ≈øcandall, and preventing the great abu≈øe of the Lords Supper; and after ≈øuch means and endeavours he is not to omit it becau≈øe of ≈øcandall, and that for the≈øe Rea≈øons:

Fir≈øt, Scandall or offence will en≈øue the very be≈øt actions. Chri≈øt is fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe to the Gentiles, a ≈øtumbling block to the Jewes, an offence to both. The Word is the ≈øavour of life and death, ≈øo is the Sacrament a poy≈øon to the unworthy Receiver, a cordiall to the Believer.

Secondly, there is not any ordinance of God at which ≈øome will not be offended. Therefore to lay a≈øide Gods Ordinances becau≈øe ≈øcandall will follow, is a ≈øtrange conclu≈øion; for offences will be in the Church till the comming of Chri≈øt.

Thirdly, Scandals are accepta, or data, taken, or given; the offence or ≈øcandal following the Lords Supper is onely taken not given; for a Mini≈øter di≈øpen≈øeth a nece≈ø≈øary Ordinance of Chri≈øt, performs a commanded duty which cannot be omitted without ≈øin, therefore the admini≈øtration of the Lords Supper cannot be ≈øaid to cau≈øe ≈øcandal. For ≈øcandal given is ≈øome way or other morally irregular, either becau≈øe evil in it ≈øelf, or becau≈øe it hath appearance of evil, and is inductive to ≈øin either from the intent of the agent, or nature of the action in it ≈øelfe. But ≈øo is not the admini≈øtration of the Lords Supper, it is neither evil in it ≈øelf, nor hath the appearance of evil, being an Ordinance of Chri≈øt. It is Bonum per ≈øe, and the omi≈ø≈øion of it is onely bonum per accidens in the ca≈øe of ≈øcandal. Now that which is good per accidens, cannot ≈øhut out that which is good per ≈øe: it is a gro≈ø≈øe ignorance that cannot di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt a fault that proceeds ex natura facti, and that which proceeds ex abu≈øu boni. The former is Malum ≈øimpliciter, the other is but Malum per accidens.
But here it may be objected, Object. that we cannot partake of the Table of the Lord, and of the Table of Devils; therefore we mu≈øt not have fellow≈øhip with the ungodly.
Fir≈øt, whether the long omi≈ø≈øion of the Lords Supper be not as great an offence to many godly hone≈øt Chri≈øtians, and cau≈øe of grief, as the admini≈øtration of it can po≈øsibly be a ≈øcandal?
Secondly, whether that good that cometh by it is not greater than the offence that is taken by any?
Thirdly, whether any duty expre≈øly commanded ought to be forborn for ≈øcandal-≈øake?
Fourthly, whether the benefit that commeth by it, be not farre greater than any evil that can follow on the admini≈øtration of it?
The Mini≈øter in giving it to the wicked and ungodly gives them poy≈øon, Object. 5 their own damnation.

The Mini≈øter di≈øpen≈øeth not poy≈øon, An≈øw. but a nece≈ø≈øary Ordinance: if it become poy≈øon it is becau≈øe of the ignorance, ≈øinfull corruption, and evil di≈øpo≈øition of the Receiver. The Mini≈øter doth but his duty, and therefore having u≈øed all lawfull means of informing, in≈øtructing, menacing, and the like, cannot be guilty of giving poy≈øon.
Secondly, here is not Occa≈øio data, ≈øed accepta, Not an occa≈øion ≈øinfully given, but ≈øinfully taken: and the Mini≈øter ≈øtandeth free from the guilt hereof.
Thirdly, a Mini≈øter doth but what his calling obligeth him to; and if the event be not good, the parties contract guilt, and pull down vengeance on them≈øelves.

The power of a Mini≈øter to admini≈øter the Lords Supper is
called by Divines Pote≈øtas ordinis, or pote≈øtas muneris ≈øpecialis, it is a Church-power more ≈øpecial, and is di≈øtingui≈øhed from the power of juri≈ødiction, which is more general and common: a Mini≈øter ought to exerci≈øe and employ for the edification of the Church all the power and authority that he may lawfully exerci≈øe. I hold the Church, ≈øaith S. Augu≈øtine, full of wheat and chaffe: I better whom I can, whom I cannot I ≈øuffer. Fugio paleam, ne hoc ≈øim; non aream, ne nihil ≈øim, I avoid the chaffe le≈øt I become chaffe; I keep the floore, le≈øt I become nothing.
Presbytery, the government of the Church is wanting, Object. 6 that ≈øhould put in practi≈øe ≈øeverity again≈øt all ungodly per≈øons.

Fir≈øt, the want of Di≈øcipline is to be lamented. An≈øw. 1 It was the ≈øaying of Bi≈øhop Jewell, All Mini≈øters have idem Ministerium, ≈øed diver≈øam pote≈øtatem. I deny not the nece≈øsity of Juri≈ødiction both Corrective and Coactive: the one re≈øtraining where there is too much forwardne≈ø≈øe; the other inforcing where there is ≈ølackne≈ø≈øe.

Secondly, all ≈øcandalous per≈øons convicted to be ≈øuch, the Church ought to ca≈øt out; but we are not to ca≈øt our ≈øelves out of the Church, and debarre our ≈øelves from the Ordinances of Chri≈øt Je≈øus.
Thirdly, if Presbytery never be ≈øetled, as is neither improbable, nor impo≈øsible; ≈øhall this nece≈ø≈øary Ordinance be never di≈øpen≈øed? God forbid.

Fourthly, the Sacrament of the Lords Supper hath been truly admini≈øtred without Presbytery, otherwi≈øe we ≈øhall ≈øhew our ≈øelves the mo≈øt uncharitable people that ever breathed, to condemn the preceding Church for many generations, and throw dirt in their faces that ≈øuffered Martyrdome for maintaining the truth, and purity of this Ordinance: I ≈øhall onely in≈øtance the admini≈øtration of the Lords Supper by our Saviour, which was mo≈øt exact and perfect in the point of E≈ø≈øentials, and a pattern for the Church, for after-times; it wanted nothing E≈ø≈øentially belonging to the true di≈øpen≈øation of it: in≈øomuch that Saint Paul ≈øticks clo≈øe unto that pattern, and telleth the Corinthians, What I have received, &c. 1 Cor. 11. Now at that time (I think none will affirm) that the Church was presbyterated, and that there were Lay Elders among≈øt the Apo≈øtles:
or that it appeareth out of Acts 2.42. & 20.7. 1 Cor. 11.24. That tho≈øe that received the Lords Supper were all examined by an Elder≈øhip,Ieanes. otherwi≈øe no admittance; the Lords Supper hath no e≈ø≈øential dependance on an Elder≈øhip, as that it cannot be without it. It is no ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary antecedent as that the Lords Supper is to be omitted or forborn for the want of it; for if Presbytery never be e≈øtabli≈øhed, ≈øhall the Lords Supper never be admini≈øtred? God forbid. The exerci≈øe of Di≈øcipline as I ≈øaid before, is not nece≈ø≈øary for the e≈ø≈øence of a vi≈øible Church, but onely nece≈ø≈øary to the welbeing of a Church. But now, all doe ≈øay, That the Sacraments are, though not ab≈øolutely, yet in ≈øome degrees nece≈ø≈øary to the e≈ø≈øence & beeing of a Church. So then, if you compare together the≈øe two duties, Exclu≈øion of ≈øcandalous and ignorant per≈øons from the Lords Supper, and the Celebration of the Lords Supper; the Obligation unto the Admini≈øtration of the Lords Supper, is of the two, the greater and more weighty. For the Lords Supper is more the wor≈øhip of God, le≈ø≈øe ≈øeparable from, and more nece≈ø≈øary to the Church than exclu≈øion of ≈øcandalous and gro≈øly ignorant per≈øons from the Lords Supper. Therefore it is altogether improbable that this latter, viz: exclu≈øion, &c. ≈øhould be an Antecedent ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary unto the former, viz: the celebration of the Lords Supper. That the Pa≈ø≈øeover and Circumci≈øion were omitted to the Children of I≈ørael in the wilderne≈ø≈øe is mo≈øt true, yet that makes nothing to this purpo≈øe. For after the fir≈øt celebration of the Pa≈ø≈øeover all future celebrations were by expre≈ø≈øe and plain command to be in the Land of Canaan, Exod. 13.4, 5. Deut. 16. from the 1≈øt to the 8th, therefore this Argument concludeth nothing.

OF the fir≈øt, Perfecting of the Saints, where let us con≈øider what is meant by Saints, and what by Perfection. Saint the Greek word is „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ and cometh from a privitive „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ

Non peccare Dei ju≈øtitia e≈øt; hominis ju≈øtitia indulgentia Dei, To be without ≈øin is the righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe of God; mans righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe is Gods indulgence pardoning of ≈øinne. The≈øe kinde of men thus ≈øwelled with pride, blown with o≈øtentation, and dreaming of ≈øelf perfection, are in a mo≈øt dangerous condition. Let the Donati≈øt drink never ≈øo deep of the ju≈øtifying. div.head: To M. and his Mates.
div.p:
IT is ≈øtoried of Publius Clodius (le≈øt Cicero ≈øhould unju≈øtly tax him of ≈øacriledge) that he ≈øtept in, and fir≈øt told the Senate, That Cicero had prophan'd all Religion in his hou≈øe. Thus he that hath the mo≈øt corrupt Lungs, ≈øoone≈øt complains of the un≈øavoury breath of others. I invite not ≈øuch, nor you Mr. M. and your company to my banquet; for, I know you are apter to fa≈øhion ≈øtrange Interpretations of what was never meant, than like civil gue≈øts, to cut fairly and re≈øpctively: you ≈øtick not to ≈øay any thing that is fal≈øe, and mi≈øapply any thing that is true. Nacri≈ø≈øus-like, you are enamoured of your own beauty, and judge your ≈øelves the fairst and refined≈øt ≈øtuffe: you must be ownd (for≈øooth) as the GODLY PARTIE: Oh! it is an injury not to give you that title you give your ≈øelves forth to be, The Temple of the Lord, Th Temple of the Lord: and if reproved, pre≈øently cry, We are Abrahams children: of all men you are the harde≈øt to be cured; for, why ≈øhould Phy≈øick be administred to tho≈øe that are perfectly ≈øound? I must take the liberty to tell you, That you forget to build up the Cedar-work of piety, and learn onely to paint over with Vermilion: to borrow the words of a worthy Divine, Men think you Saints, you think your ≈øelves Angels, Flatterers make you Gods, and GOD knows
you are Devils; and will ≈ømite ≈øuch painted walls, and rotten gilded po≈øts.
It is not ami≈ø≈øe to give ≈øome Characters of you, that you may be known and avoided.
1. The be≈øt things publi≈øhed, with the be≈øt intent, ≈øcape not the la≈øh of your cen≈øure: he that doth not dance after your pipe ≈øhall be ≈øure to be ≈øcoured, and ≈øcourged.
2. Malice and Envy are ≈øeated in your looks, and you let ≈ølip no advantage that may accompli≈øh your own ends, though to the ruine of your neighbours.

3. You are tender of no mans Reputation, (if be cro≈ø≈øe your humours) his name, fame, and credit ≈øhall be ≈øhipwrackt, and all the ≈øcandals and contumelies that can be imagined ≈øhall be layd to his charge to render him vile and odious.
4. Before you want matter for per≈øecution, bare information ≈øhall ≈øerve your turn: contrary to the Law of God or man.
5. You are knowne by your lofty lookes, envenomed tongues, cruell hands, ≈øurly ≈øalutations, and imperious commands.
6. Perfoetorem oris, By your ≈øtinking breath, which proceeds either from ≈øome hot di≈øtemper of your mouth, rotten humours in the ≈øtomach, or ulceration of the lungs.

If Mr. M. and his crew finde fault with my tartne≈ø≈øe, let them know, half is not told: Emendate vitam, ego emendabo verba, Mend your waies, and I will mend my words. Ce≈ø≈øate pervers√® agere, Cea≈øe from doing evil, and I will cea≈øe to reprove and rebuke: I pray God give you ≈øober judgments, peaceable ≈øpirits, devotion with profe≈øsion, Zeale without envy, love without partiality, and Religion with Go≈øpel. charity; for, were you guided by this (as they that will be Judges of other mens actions ought to
be) you would forbear to cen≈øure or condemn; but if my prayers prove ineffectuall, and that your flinty hearts cannot be broken; know, that your ≈øharp frosts, and nipping blasts ≈øhall not marre the beauty, or enervate the vertue of my flouri≈øhing tree, which (God a≈øsi≈øting) ≈øhall ≈øtand un≈øhaken in your greate≈øt ≈øtorms. My Saviour came once with Pax vobis, Peace be unto you: at another time with Vae vobis! Woe be unto you! The ≈øearching wine of Reprehen≈øion, to eat out the dead fle≈øh, is for you more nece≈ø≈øary, than the oyle of Con≈øolation. Woe unto them that prophe≈øie to ≈øuch as you are ≈ømooth things, and deceits, I≈øa. 30.10, 11. Yet if any be ≈øo bold as to bring ≈øowre grapes, and the ≈øharp wine of reproofs, and you once come to be fretted with the ju≈øt Reprehen≈øion of your Hypocri≈øie, then farewell Pa≈øtor, expect expul≈øion from thy poor Vineyard, thou ≈øhalt finde the≈øe fiery Serpents, (where≈øoever thou goest) with their venemous and burning ≈øtings, wounding thy per≈øon, doctrine, name, fame, and what≈øoever is dearest to thee.

I conclude you men of ill temper'd con≈øtitutions, all earth in your hearts, all water in your ≈øtomachs, all aire in your brains, and all fire in your tongues; your hearts heavy, your ≈øtomachs ≈øurfeited and watry, your brains light and a√´rie, your tongues flaming, and fiery, you never are at re≈øt, but like the troubled Sea, ca≈øt up myre and dirt.

div.head: The per≈øecuted MINISTER, In defence of the MINISTERIE, The great Ordinance of JESUS CHRIST. THE SECOND PART.
div.p:
HAving begun a Di≈øcour≈øe of ≈øeverall things touching the Mini≈øterie, as in the Fir≈øt Part of this Book, the heads of which are layd down in the Title Page, I intend (by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance) to treat,
1. Of the continuance of the Mini≈øterie.
2. What is required to the con≈øtituting of Go≈øpel-Mini≈øters.
3. The excellency and dignity of their calling.
4. What re≈øpect they ought to bee of among≈øt Chri≈øtians.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: Ephe≈ø. 4.13. Of the continuance of the Mini≈øterie till the end of the world, and that as long as there is a Church, there will be Pa≈øtors and Teachers.

div.p: FOr the continuance of the Mini≈øterial Office, it is not temporary but la≈øting, and mu≈øt remain unto the end of the world,Ephe≈ø. 4.13. [untill we all come to the unity of the faith, and of &c.]

This Unity, in the Text, hath a double relation:
1. To Faith.
2. To Knowledge. And the object of both is Chri≈øt.

Faith is taken pa≈ø≈øively, Adams, The Saints meeting. or actively; either for that whereby a man believeth, or for that which a man believeth; either for the in≈øtrument that apprehendeth, or for the object that is apprehended. Now if we take it for the form, there is an Unity of Faith, Ratione objecti, non ratione ≈øubjecti, One in re≈øpect of the object on which it re≈øts; not one, in re≈øpect of the ≈øubject in which it remaineth; every man hath his proper faith, and every faith hath Chri≈øt for its object: he that ≈øeeth, mu≈øt ≈øee with his own eyes; he that feeleth, mu≈øt feel with his own hands; he that entreth into the man≈øion of glory, mu≈øt have oyle ready in his own lamp; the ju≈øt ≈øhall live by his own faith, and we ≈øhall all meet in the unity of one holy Catholick faith. Now if we take it in the other ≈øen≈øe for Chri≈øt, in whom we have believed, we ≈øhall meet undoubtedly in the unity of tho≈øe joyes and comforts which we have long expected; and all Believers ≈øince the Creation till the worlds Di≈ø≈øolution ≈øhall meet in the unity of faith.

Secondly, there ≈øhall be Unity of Knowledge at the la≈øt day, though the manner of knowing cea≈øeth, yet the matter remaineth; all our knowledge in this life is through the ≈øpectacles of faith, in the gla≈ø≈øe of the Scriptures; we ≈øee in part, we know imperfectly, we behold Chri≈øt through the latte≈ø≈øe, Cant. 2.9. darkly through a gla≈ø≈øe, 1 Cor. 13.12. but in heaven we ≈øhall
know him face to face; we ≈øhall live by ≈øight, not by faith: faith and hope ≈øhall vani≈øh, there ≈øhall be onely fruition in heaven; and in this we ≈øhall all meet, 1 Joh. 3.2.

To a perfect man; full perfection is re≈øerved for heaven, when our reunited bodies and ≈øoules ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe perfect glory, and reign with our Saviour for ever. We are ≈øaid here to be one body who≈øe head is Chri≈øt, 1 Cor. 12.27. but there, one perfect man; and in truth the expre≈ø≈øion is very patheticall, for the Saints in glory cannot be called a body, for a body receives augmentation, encrea≈øe, and growth; ≈øo this my≈øticall body encrea≈øeth with the encrea≈øe of God, Col. 2.19. Now in heaven there is no augmentation, encrea≈øe, and growth, therefore are the Saints compared to a perfect man.

To the mea≈øure of the Stature; not that all in heaven ≈øhall be of that age wherein Chri≈øt died, onely it denotes that there ≈øhall be nothing wanting to make our glory perfect; here we ≈øhoot out ≈øome few boughs, bring forth ≈øome little fruit, we grow as fa≈øt as we can, adding to faith, virtue; to virtue, knowledge; but there we ≈øhall have a full mea≈øure of ≈øanctity, of comfort, of bli≈ø≈øe, of glory, of the fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt.

Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe is to be con≈øidered per≈øonally, or my≈øtically; per≈øonally in him≈øelf, and ≈øo he is not onely perfect, but perfection, Col. 1.19. in him dwelleth not onely a ≈øufficient fulne≈øs, but all the fulne≈øs; not of any created nature, but of the Godhead; not phanta≈øtically, but bodily.

2. It is to be con≈øidered my≈øtically, or in relation to his Church, who ≈øhall be gathered together to the head, and partake of the fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt. The words thus explained, there ari≈øeth from hence this truth:
That the office and function of the Mini≈øtery is not temporary,Ob≈ø. but perpetuall, that is, mu≈øt remain till the Saints be perfected in glory, it mu≈øt continue till we all meet, &c.

God was the fir≈øt Teacher and Doctour of the world, as he was in him≈øelfe, ≈øo in his teaching wonderfull; in proce≈ø≈øe of time this Divine wi≈ødome thought it nece≈ø≈øary to u≈øe outward in≈øtruments, and to teach the ≈øons of men, by Men; yet through various di≈øpen≈øations, Hebr. 1.1. God can give ≈øpirituall life without the ordinary means; he can maintain a naturall life
without bread, he can give wi≈ødome without a Teacher, nothing to him is impo≈øsible, but what is to us naturall, ≈øin, and defects: though God can doe all things by his ab≈øolute power, yet it is his will to ordain his Word as the ordinary means of ≈øalvation, to give men knowledge by in≈øtruction, and ≈øave by teaching. Thus Cornelius was taught by Peter, Lydia by Paul, Paul by Ananias, the Eunuch by Philip, Every Soul that is wi≈øe in the Doctrine of Salvation by Apo≈øtles, Prophets, Evangelifts, Pa≈øtors, and Feachers appointed for the gathering together of the Saints for the work, &c. When the Lord intended a ble≈ø≈øing to his people, he made them this promi≈øe, I will give you Pa≈øtors according to my heaert, that ≈øhall feed you with knowledge and under≈øtanding. Now the Lord hath not at any time cea≈øed, and left off, but from the infancy of the world to this pre≈øent hour hath continued the Mini≈øtery to his Church; Chri≈øt gives his Apo≈øtles a Commi≈øsion, Mat. 28.19. Go teach all Nations; and concludes with a promi≈øe, ver≈øe 20. Loe I am with you alwaies, &c. God will ≈øend ≈øhepherds till every lo≈øt ≈øheep be brought to his fold; the Mini≈øters voice ≈øhall ≈øound, till the Archangels voice be heard.Art. 23. Pro. 4. This is the Doctrine of the Church of England. And the late A≈ø≈øembly of Divines hath this expre≈øsion, Unto the Catholick vi≈øible Church,chap. 25.3. Chri≈øt hath given the Mini≈øters, Oracles and Ordinances of God, for the gathering and perfecting of the Saints in this life to the end of the world. You reade the Mini≈øtration of the Law had an end, but the Mini≈øtration of the Go≈øpel hath no end, till the world end; God hath made us, ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle, able Mini≈øters of the New Te≈øtament, not of the Letter, but of the spirit; the letter killeth, but the ≈øpirit giveth life, 2 Cor. 3.6. The proper office of the Law is to terrifie, to condemn; but the power of the Go≈øpel is to convert, to ≈øave. Mo≈øes glory is done away, the type is vani≈øhed; but Chri≈øts glory remains, and abides for ever: after the fir≈øt Te≈øtament, there did follow a ≈øecond; but after the ≈øecond, there ≈øhall ≈øucceed none: the Go≈øpel in the Revelations, Rev. 14.6. is called, the everla≈øting Gospel. The Mini≈øtery of the Go≈øpel (≈øaith Zanchy) begun with Chri≈øt, and ≈øhall end with the world; but the power of it is everla≈øting, A condito orbe u≈øque in omnem aeternitatem duratura, for it is the power of
God unto ≈øalvation unto every one that believeth: not onely is it called ≈øo in regard of the power of it; but that everla≈øting life is the ≈øubject of it: it holds forth eternall life, and is the common ordinary means of bringing us thither; as the blood of Chri≈øt mu≈øt be for the ≈øaving of ≈øinners to the end of the world, ≈øo his Go≈øpel mu≈øt be preached that the people may be taught how this blood mu≈øt be applied.

As long as there is a Church upon earth which will be to the end of the world, Mat. 16.18. Thou art Peter, and upon &c. God can a≈ø≈øoon forget him≈øelfe, as his promi≈øe; cea≈øe to be God, as cea≈øe to be faithfull: As long, I ≈øay, as there is a Church on Earth, ≈øo long mu≈øt there be Teachers in and for the edifying of the Church, 1 Cor. 12 28. and ≈øo here he hath given ≈øome Apo≈øtles, ≈øome Prophets &c. Experience telleth us, there are Wolves as full of craft as cruelty, who de≈øiring to devour their flock, endeavour the removall of the Shepherds, but Pan curat oves ovi√∫mque magi≈øtros. Our great Shepherd pre≈øerveth his ≈øheep and ≈øhepherds. He that hath given the Mini≈øtery to his Church, will (maugre the malice of all oppo≈øition) maintain that order in it, and keep fa≈øt tho≈øe ≈øtars in his right hand, Revel. 1.16. that none can pluck them thence; it is true, the great red Dragon with his tayle, Rev. 12. hath drawn away a great part of the ≈øtarres of our heaven, and ca≈øt them to the earth; yet ≈øtill ≈øome abide in their orbes to give light to this crooked Generation; and let us pray the Father of Lights to continue them, and to fix more and more burning and ≈øhining lights in our firmament, and ≈øuffer no longer wandring ≈øtarres, Jude 13. and ignes fatuos to mi≈øleade his people into bogs and precipices. What hath been ≈øpoken may ≈øerve

Fir≈øt, to refute the errour of ≈øuch, as ≈øay and affirm, That there is no Mini≈øtery, the Apo≈øtles are dead, their calling cea≈øed with them: of this opinion is Epi≈øcopius, O≈øtorodius, and others. Some affirm, that the Mini≈øters calling is onely for orders ≈øake, but a thing not nece≈ø≈øary by Divine in≈øtitution. Some crie it down as u≈øele≈ø≈øe and needle≈ø≈øe, and condemn the Mini≈øterie of the Word, and Sacraments, as poor, low, empty, and naked things.

Secondly, from hence we may take notice of Gods great love to his Church, from time to time, rai≈øing up Prophets, Evangeli≈øts, Pa≈øtors, and Teachers, whereby Sathans dominion is weakned, Chri≈øts kingdome advanced, being the means of daily intercour≈øe betwixt God and man; ≈øpeaking unto them as a man to his friend, and be≈øeeching them by us (through Chri≈øt) to be reconciled to him; it is a very ≈øad and uncomfortable thing when the Lord depriveth a Nation of this ble≈ø≈øing: when the Lord meant happine≈ø≈øe to his people, he made them this promi≈øe, I will give you Pa≈øtors according to my heart, which ≈øha feed you with knowledge and understanding; but to deprive you of this, is a token, that ruine and de≈øtruction is at hand, unthankfull are that people that will not acknowledge the wonderfull ble≈ø≈øing of God in the Mini≈øtery: the want of this, doubtle≈ø≈øe, is one of the greate≈øt judgments that can befall a people So the Lord threatneth Amos 8.11. to be debarred of the glad tydings of ≈øalvation, and not hear the ≈øound of the Go≈øpel, but wander in darkne≈ø≈øe, and ignorance, mu≈øt needs be a heart-breaking and heart-tormenting ≈øorrow: The Lord out of his love giveth Mini≈øters to his Church, and they are for their works ≈øake to be beloved, and prayed for; for if the Lord ≈øhould totally eclip≈øe the≈øe Lights, it would be the darke≈øt, and di≈ømall'≈øt day that ever your eyes beheld. Divines have ≈øeverall opinions upon that place of the P≈øalmi≈øt, P≈øal 45 9. ∆≤pon thy right hand did ≈øtand the Queen in gold of Ophir; ≈øo the Original: but in the other Tran≈ølation of the P≈øal: it is read, In a ve≈øture of gold wrought about &c. To clear this expo≈øition from novelty, you mu≈øt know,
1. That the Septuagint reads it ≈øo, who≈øe tran≈ølation is u≈øed by Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles.
Secondly, the Antient Fathers for the mo≈øt part interpret the words ≈øo.
Thirdly, the clau≈øe [wrought about with divers colours] is nothing el≈øe but a periphra≈øis of the Hebrew, Cethem.

Fourthly, David ≈øeems ≈øo to expand him≈øelf, ver≈øe 14. ≈øpeaking of this Queen, She ≈øhall be brought unto the King in garment of needlework; that is, of various and divers colours. Thus much for the clearing of the words. The matter of the Churches apparell
is gold; her trimming [embroydered with divers colours] is the righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe of Christ; the hand that putteth this on is faith; the cla≈øps that tie this clo≈øe together, are the Sacraments: But there are other Expo≈øitions upon the words, [Divers colours,] which is not ami≈ø≈øe to in≈øert; ≈øome under≈øtand, divers virtues, according to that of Saint Paul, Col. 3.12. Put on tender mercies &c. Some by this under≈øtand the divers kinds of precepts in the Scriptures: Some morall, others naturall; ≈øome theoricall, others practicall; ≈øome legall, others Evangelicall. Some by [Divers colours,] under≈øtand Contemplation and Action. Some under≈øtand this of tho≈øe graces and gifts of the Spirit, mentioned, 1 Cor. 12. Others of tho≈øe degrees and orders in the Church, Some Apo≈øtles, ≈øome Prophets, &c. The≈øe are the embroideries of the Church; with the≈øe the Lord doth clothe her, and make her happy; without which, ≈øhe is poor and naked. Oh! where is your, and the Nations thankfulne≈ø≈øe? what could God Almighty have done more, that he hath not done, ≈øending Labourers into his Vineyard? ≈øome ploughing up the fallow ground, others binding the brokenhearted, leaving no means unattempted to make us happy; yet have we not manife≈øted our thankfulne≈ø≈øe to the Father of Lights, for giving us ≈øuch Lights Nay, rather doe not many contemn and de≈øpi≈øe, revile, and rayle again≈øt them, and look upon them as the every ≈øcum and off ≈øcouring of the earth? They, who≈øe lips God hath ≈øea≈øoned, and ≈øeal'd to pre≈øerve knowledge, are held contemptible; and their feet foule, that bring the faire≈øt me≈ø≈øage: the Prophets labour to cure Jeru≈øalem, but Jeru≈øalem labours to kill her Prophets, a ≈øtrange requital! Many kill us whom we would cure (though not in our naturall) yet in our civill life, our reputation; though we feel not actuall murtherings, we are ≈øen≈øible of cruell murmurings. I≈øhmaels tongue made him a per≈øecutor, a≈øwell as E≈øau's hand. I tremble to con≈øider to what malice and envy this holy calling is expo≈øed, as S. Paul ≈øaith, We are made a gazing-≈øtock to the world, to men, and Angels, 1 Cor. 4.9. ≈øilent, in Gods cau≈øe zealous; for private injuries we are to pa≈ø≈øe them by with a Father forgive them: but when the cau≈øe of the Go≈øpel ≈øuffers, and is wounded in the reproach of the Mini≈øtery, we are not to be ≈øilent. Chri≈øt when he was reviled, reviled not again, when he was per≈øecuted, 1 Pet. 2.23. &c. but when accu≈øed of bla≈øphemy, Luke 11.15. he an≈øwers, he makes apologie for him≈øelf, and confutes his adver≈øaries by ≈øeverall arguments, ver≈øe 17. and ≈øo on. But more of this in its proper place.

Thirdly, if God give his Church this priviledge of the Mini≈øtery, they may expect a priviledge of God, that is, protection; Hath his wi≈ødome ≈øent them? and ≈øhall not his power protect them? I ≈øend you forth in the mid≈øt of wolves; 'tis true: but the ≈øame Chri≈øt ≈øaith, I am with you alwaies, &c. We mu≈øt fight with Bea≈øts, as did S. Poul, 1 Cor. 15 32. with ravening Wolves, with Devils under the name of Saints. With unrea≈øonable men, 2 The≈ø. 3.2. Yet we are to comfort our ≈øelves, that he that ≈øent us, will protect us, and being his Amba≈ø≈øadours, he will requite our injuries, and look upon them as done to him≈øelf; For he that de≈øpi≈øeth you, &c. The di≈øgraces done to them, the Lord accounteth them done to him≈øelf, Exod. 16.8. What are we?‚Äîyour murmurings are not again≈øt us, but again≈øt the Lord. The di≈øgraces of Gods Prophets and Mini≈øters are alwaies rewarded with Gods judgments.
